results.title: Momentum: a crash course
results.creator_credit: Shane Mulcahy, Jim Joyce, Trish Pilley and Box Hill College of Technical and Further Education
results.brief_description: Uses simple collision between ice-skaters and gliders on an air track to develop the concepts of momentum and impulse and shows how these can be used in conjunction with the principles of conservation of momentim to analyse the changes in motion that occur in collisions.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Shane Mulcahy, Jim Joyce, Trish Pilley and Box Hill College of Technical and Further Education

results.title: Countering sexism
results.creator_credit: Don Fitzsimmons, Julie Sheehan, Sabina Baltrukomis and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: A compilation tape of four programmes addressing various aspects of sex discrimination. The episodes highlight women working in the media, the importance of gender inclusive curriculum, girls and science and sexual harrassment in schools.

results.title: Social enquiry: questions, answers and action
results.creator_credit: Bob Scarfe and Victoria. Schools Division. Curriculum Branch
results.brief_description: Looks at two classes, one at year 4 and one at year 10, engaged in effective enquiry learning. Both are investigating local issues involving the environment, plus the decision making processes that enable change to take place. Different stages of the enquiry sequence are featured which allow observations to be made about teaching strategies and the learning processes.

results.title: 'Way to go'
results.brief_description: Overviews school camps and excursions. Explains who is responsible for these events, the planning and approvals required prior to the trip, teacher and student preparation and legal and safety requirements.

results.title: Partners in curriculum
results.creator_credit: Diane O'Connor and Victoria. Schools Division. Curriculum Branch
results.brief_description: A program which encourages the participation of teachers, students, parents and school based groups and committees in the planning and development of school curriculum. Examples of how this is happening at Mt. Clear High School, Tallangatta High School and Williamstown High School are shown. Curriculum support services are also briefly mentioned.

results.title: Schools working with curriculum frameworks
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, David Ferris and Victoria. Schools Division. Curriculum Branch
results.brief_description: Trevor Lunn introduces a panel including Dr. Max Stephens, Anne Gooding, Mary Weaven, Enid Mayfield, Geoff Whyte, Denis Cunningham and Geoff Burt who explain how the key ideas and issues of Curriculum Frameworks are being addressed by Schools. This panel of teachers and regional consultants discuss several specific frameworks areas.

results.title: Rhythm
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Lessons in visual language”.
Devised and narrated by Peter Thompson. Explores rhythm as a fundamental part of the langauge of motion pictures and its integral role in film making. Addresses: 1. Rhythm does not depend on cutting 2. Changes of shot do not necessarily have any special rhythmic effect 3. Music can impose its own rhythm 4. Music and images can work together.

results.title: Cutout animation
results.creator_credit: Davis Johnson, Eric Halliday and AFTRS
results.brief_description: A very good hands-on type film which will show students a way of getting into animation by some means other than drawing. A similar type of animation as seen in the opening credits of the Monty Python Show is shown.

results.title: Analysis of a television commercial
results.creator_credit: Vass Contis, Eric Halliday and AFTRS
results.brief_description: Eric Halliday interviews Bruce Kerridge, producer of the Mining Industry Council commercials and Dr. Ian Mills, a La Trobe University lecturer who indicate reasons for the production of a commercial and a method for interpreting the same.
